content:
The Act may be cited as the "Clean Energy Partnership with India Act of 2008" and defines renewable energy. The "Clean Energy Partnership with India Act of 2008" defines renewable energy as reliable, affordable, and environmentally friendly technologies that reduce greenhouse gas emissions or increase geological sequestration. The "Clean Energy Partnership with India Act of 2008" defines renewable energy as technologies that reduce greenhouse gas emissions and may result in reduced air pollutants or less hazardous waste generation. The Congressional Commission on Renewable Power Technology Commerce with India is established to study and promote bilateral renewable energy cooperation between the United States and India. The Commission will recommend joint energy policy strategies between the US and India for reliable renewable energy in India. The report will include market conditions, policy constraints, and best practices for investment in renewable energy production and distribution in India. The Commission will recommend strategies for renewable energy collaboration between the US and India, addressing constraints for US renewable technology companies investing in India. Recommendations will focus on policy measures and joint research opportunities for optimal energy production and distribution. The Commission will recommend strategies for renewable energy collaboration between the US and India, focusing on policy measures and joint research opportunities for optimal energy production and distribution, as well as the ideal role for energy-related end-user devices in an energy efficiency policy. SEC. 103. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, House minority leader, Senate majority leader, and Senate minority leader. The President designates the Chairperson from the members appointed by the President. Members must meet certain qualifications for appointment. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by various officials. Members must have expertise in renewable energy, energy transmission, energy efficiency, business, entrepreneurship, academia, or public policy. Appointments must be made within 60 days of enactment, and members serve for the life of the Commission with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Each member of the Commission may be compensated at a rate not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for a position at level IV of the Executive Schedule. They shall also receive travel expenses and per diem while away from their home or regular place of business. Federal employees are prohibited from receiving compensation. The Commission members cannot receive additional pay if they are federal employees or Members of Congress. The Commission must meet quarterly, with additional meetings called by the Chairperson or majority. Five members constitute a quorum, and meetings can be held via telephone or technology. Members of the Commission can meet via telephone or suitable technology if all members can communicate simultaneously. SEC. 104. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a director appointed by the chairperson with the approval of the majority of members. The director must have recognized standing in public service or service-learning. The salary of the director is determined by the chairperson and cannot exceed the maximum rate of basic pay for GS-15. The director of the Commission may appoint additional staff and fix their pay, not exceeding the maximum rate of basic pay for GS-15. The director can also hire experts and consultants at rates not exceeding the maximum annual rate of basic pay for GS-15. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission may appoint staff and hire experts to assist in carrying out its duties under this title. SEC. 105. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold public hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain official data from government departments. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can also use the United States mails and access physical facilities and equipment. The Architect of the Capitol provides facilities and equipment for the Commission on a nonreimbursable basis. The Commission can request administrative support services from the Architect of the Capitol and the Administrator of General Services. The Commission has contract authority to compensate agencies or persons for services necessary to carry out its duties. SEC. 106. REPORTS.

Interim Report due within 12 months of enactment, Final Report due within 120 days of Interim Report. Commission terminates 30 days after submitting Final Report.

TITLE II--DEVELOPMENT AND CAPACITY BUILDING REPORT

SEC. 201. DEVELOPMENT AND CAPACITY BUILDING REPORT. The Secretary of State, in consultation with the Secretary of Energy and the Secretary of Commerce, must submit a report to Congress within one year of the enactment of this Act. The report will detail the availability of energy in India, the investment potential for US industry in renewable energy production, the economic benefits of meeting India's energy needs with renewable energy, and the greenhouse gas emissions if India does not pursue renewable energy. The report will provide recommendations for the Federal Government and private sector to support renewable energy production in India. TITLE III--RENEWABLE ENERGY COUNCIL

SEC. 301. RENEWABLE ENERGY COUNCIL. Establishment of a permanent joint renewable energy council between the United States and India within 60 days of the enactment of this Act. The council's purpose is to advise the Presidents of both countries on promoting environmentally sustainable economic growth through renewable energy investment, production, and distribution. Membership includes representatives from the legislative and executive branches of both governments and the private sector. The establishment of a permanent joint renewable energy council between the United States and India within 60 days of the enactment of this Act, with membership including representatives from the private sector in both countries.
